questiontext.text:
By expressing the integrand as the sum of its partial fractions, find the following definite integral: \[ \int^{@rdm4@}_{@rdm5@} {@p@} d{@v@}. \]
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
In order to calculate \[\int {@p@} d{@v@}\] we need to express \[{@p@}\] as the sum of its partial fractions <hint>alg_partial_fractions</hint>.
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle {@p@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@factor(p)@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@A@}{@ppp1@} + {@B@}{@ppp2@} \end{array}\]
Omitting details we have \[{@p@} = {@q@},\] hence,
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \int {@p@} d{@v@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \int {@q@} d{@v@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@rdm2@} \int {@ppp1@} d{@v@} + {@rdm3@} \int {@ppp2@} d{@v@} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@rdm2*int(ppp1,v)@} + {@rdm3*int(ppp2,v)@} +c \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@rdm2*int(ppp1,v)+rdm3*int(ppp2,v)@} +c \end{array}\]
We need \[\int^{@rdm4@}_{@rdm5@} {@p@} d{@v@}\] so, recall that if \[\int f(x) dx = F(x)\] then \[\int^a_b f(x) dx = F(a) - F(b).\]
Thus, define \[F({@v@}) = {@int(q,v)@}\]
Then,
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \int^{@rdm4@}_{@rdm5@} {@p@} d{@v@} &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle F({@rdm4@}) - F({@rdm5@}) \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@subst(rdm4,v,pq)@} - \left[{@subst(rdm5,v,pq)@}\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle {@subst(rdm4,v,pq)-subst(rdm5,v,pq)@} \end{array}\]
